questions.question: ……………………. it prove to be true, I shall resign from my job.
questions.description: Should is often used instead of if in conditional clauses to express the idea that something is very unlikely.

questions.question: …………………… it possible, I would buy that apartment.
questions.description: Were is often used in the second conditional to talk about improbable situations.

questions.question: If you exercised regularly, you ………………………… become strong and healthy.
questions.description: In the second conditional we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: The more he studies, ………………………
questions.description: The same structure is used in both clauses.

questions.question: Is she ……………………….. to be a grandmother?
questions.description: As an adverb enough is used after the adjective it modifies.

questions.question: She has been staying with her parents ………………………. January.
questions.description: We use since to indicate the starting point.

questions.question: …………………….. having many faults, he was actually a nice guy.
questions.description: Despite is a preposition. It is used before a noun or ing form.

questions.question: ………………………… she was not perfect, I couldn’t help admiring her.
questions.description: Although is a conjunction. Use it before a clause.

questions.question: I felt like ………………………… but I didn’t dare to.
questions.description: We use an ing form after felt like.

questions.question: We didn’t have any trouble ……………………….. him.
If you don’t understand, don’t hesitate ………………………. questions.
